intro_1: ^You're a full-time Uber driver trying to make ends meet.
^You have one week to try to make $1000. Can you do it?

choose_difficulty: ^First, pick your character. Do you live in San Francisco or in Sacramento, where rent is cheaper?
car_choice: ^Now it's time to get a car. You'll have to lease one

b: ^. Your good credit rating gets you a better deal.
^, which will cost more due to your poor credit.

car_choice: ^The Prius is more fuel efficient, but the minivan qualifies for UberXL rides, which earn a higher fare.

c: ^ You pick the Toyota Prius. It costs $
^ per week, and can get up to 50 miles per gallon
^ You picked the Dodge minivan. It costs $
^ per week, but UberXL rides earn higher fares

s0: ^Let's get you set up to drive with a few accessories.

c: ^Unlimited data plan: Since you have to be constantly connected to the Uber app, this will save you from paying overage charges.
^: Every driver has one to hold their phone, so they can use it with one hand while keeping their eyes on the road. And you don't want to run out of batteries on your phone.
^: In case someone makes a mess in your car
^: You are technically running a business as an independent contracter to Uber
^: You could go work out, but the main perk is having a place to shower and freshen up.

day_1_start: ^You start bright and early on a Monday morning.

weekday_quest_message: ^ extra. Now, until Friday May 26, 4 am"

day_1_sacramento: ^Fares in Sacramento are about a third less than in a big city like San Francisco. Do you drive 2 hours to San Francisco to work there instead?"

c: ^ "You decide to try your luck in San Francisco"
^You stay in Sacramento. You'll earn less but at least you're close to home.

go_to_sf: ^You turn your app on as you drive, and you score a ride as you approach San Francisco that takes you all the way into the city.
sac_morning: ^Pretty soon, you earn your first fare: a $6 ride that took just 15 minutes to complete.
stay_or_go: ^At this rate, you're unlikely to meet your financial target.

c: ^ There's still time to salvage today. You cross the Oakland Bay bridge and arrive in San Francisco just after lunch.

sac_lunch: ^You like driving in a familiar town. You grab a quick lunch at your favourite burrito place."

c: ^ You head home, in time for dinner.
^ Things should pick up during rush hour and dinner time.
^ By this point, it doesn't really make sense to make the two-hour trip to San Francisco. You decide to stay in Sacramento, regretting that you didn't go earlier.

sac_evening: ^You start getting more ride requests, and drive until the evening crowd thins out.
^You call it a day after the evening crowd thins out.

day_1_sf: ^You start driving, and pretty soon get your first passenger. The short trip to the Mission took you 15 minutes, and you earned $10

c: ^You feel great about earning your first fare. This is easy money!

sf_morning: ^You spend a productive morning working, with little downtime in between rides.

c: ^You stop for lunch when you spot a Señor Sisig food truck. Their burritos are amazing as always.

b: ^It's pretty stressful driving in big city like San Francisco, but you think you've made the right decision.
^You get back online just in time for the busy evening period.
^ hours, and are starting to get tired.

c: ^You get home by 10pm, and get a good night's rest.
^The evening is the busiest period, but soon you're too tired to continue
^You feel much better after a quick shower at the gym. You do good business during the busy evening period.
^You decide to call it a day.

b: ^You drive 2 hours back home to Sacramento. It's pretty late by the time you get back.
^You're dead tired by the time you head back. Fortunately you manage to stay awake and arrive home without getting into an accident.

day_1_end: ^It's the end of the first day.

b: ^You wake up a bit earlier and drive out to San Francisco.

gas_receipt: ^You stop to fill up your tank. Do you get a receipt?

c: ^You keep it in a folder for your expenses.
^You don’t have time to keep track of stuff like that.

burgers: ^You get a trip request from a burger joint, and when you arrive the passengers have two juicy In N Out burgers that they are about to eat in the car.
^"The food can’t come in the car"

c: ^"Aww, come on," they say. "We'll be careful."
^," you say, as you cancel their ride.
^But soon, you find that your driver rating has fallen.
^," you say. They get in the car.
^They get in the car and you start driving.

g-0: ^From the rear-view mirror, you see one of them take a bite, and some ketchup drips onto the seat."

c: ^ After your admonishment, they wipe the seat, but there's still a stain. They look unhappy at being called out.
^ They blithely continue eating. You can't stop thinking about the stain.

g-0: ^"They finish their burgers. The rest of the trip passes without incident."

dirty_car: ^What do you do about your dirty backseat?

c: ^ You pull over and clean the back seat. As you start cleaning, a ride request comes in.
^You abandon the cleaning and go pick up the passenger. He's not impressed with the dirty backseat.
^ You put it out of your mind. Your next passenger is not too impressed with the dirty backseat.

day_2_evening: ^ hours. Do you want to push on for the evening peak period?

c: ^You deserve a break. You meet up with some friends for dinner instead.

pebble_start: ^As you drive along the highway, a pebble hits your windshield and leaves a chip.

repair: ^You find a nearby auto shop. They take an hour to fix your windscreen, and charge you $30.

nice_passenger: ^You pick up a friendly passenger and have a pleasant chat during the ride. After you drop her off, you get a notification.

c: ^ Your rating has gone up to
^As you pull up for the next pick-up, you find, annoyingly, that it's for a long trip to the airport.

^She shouts as you as you pull away. Fortunately, the rest of the rides were short ones. You finish after two hours.
^You take her to the airport. You didn't want to get in the queue for a ride back, so you drive back to town by yourself. You decide to call it a day and finish the quest tomorrow instead.

day_4_quest_completed: ^Since you've already finished the quest and the next one won't start until Friday, do you want to take the day off?

c: ^You spend the day with your family. Your son is glad you made time for him, and you get some much needed rest.
^You need every penny you can earn.

day_5_evening: ^It's 8pm, and you just dropped off a passenger in the Financial District in the northeast of San Francisco.

c: ^: Surge pricing in the Sunset district. Earn 3x fares!

surge: ^The 3x fare is attractive, but it might be gone by the time you get to the Sunset district, which is 30 minutes away.

c: ^Tripling your earning is just too tempting. You start driving over to the surge zone, but the roads are busy and the traffic lights are not on your side tonight.
^You are three blocks away when the surge ends. You are annoyed at having wasted half an hour.
^You ignore the message. You are doing good enough business without it.

home_or_not: ^When you can finally take time for a break, it's already past midnight.

day_6_deactivated: ^It's Saturday. You wake up and check your Uber app to find that you're still deactivated.You decide to make the most of your enforced day off.

c: ^You spend a relaxing afternoon in the park with your son. It sure feels good to not have to sit in a car all day.

b: ^Your son was still mad at you for letting him down on Thursday, but brightened up significantly by the end of the day.

day_6_slept_in_car: ^You wake up, briefly forgetting that you're in your car in San Francisco.
day_6_start: ^It's Saturday. Do you take the day off? It is the weekend, after all.

day_6_work: ^The San Francisco Giants are playing at AT&T park today. Earn a boosted 1.5x fare for trips from there, from 5pm-6:30pm today
door_dent: ^As you finish a ride, the passenger opens the door to get out and hits a lamp post, denting your car door. He is apologetic, but in a rush, and tells you to resolve it with Uber.

c: ^ Uber promises to investigate, but in the meantime your account is suspended. There's nothing else you can do today.
^ You decide to get it repaired yourself. It takes the mechanics two hours to fix it, and they charge you $100.
^You make your way to the baseball stadium before the game ends. Sure enough, lots of people are requesting rides there. You get lucky with a relatively long ride to Outer Richmond, and earn $30

day_6_evening: ^It sure is busy this Saturday evening.

day_7_end: ^It's the end of the week. Were you savvy enough to survive as a full-time Uber driver?
